message:
"I hate code, and I want as little of it as possible in our product. – Jack Diederich
On some of my most productive days, when I've felt that I've truly generated lots of value for my employer relative to my salary, the end result from an entire day worth of work was 3-5 lines of code . Other great efforts that I'm really proud of is removing thousands of lines of code from a project."

Does everyone else share the same sentiment? I personally do find this notion of how many lines of code per hour to be fundamentally wrong but it's also interesting that I too believe the very best work days I've had in the past 10 years were spent removing code than writing code.
story: Hady Ahmed shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: How many lines of code do professional programmers write per hour?
caption: quora.com
description: Mattias Petter Johansson's answer: > "I hate code, and I want as little of it as possible in our product." – Jack Diederich On some of my most productive days, when I've felt that I've truly generated lots of value for my employer relative to my salary, the end result from an entire day worth ...

data.message: Good programmers who eliminate code not who increase it.

Hady Ahmad totally agree with you. My best working days were those I spent them refactoring old code and minimize the amount of code to solve a specific problem. I always feel like a ninja when I do :D
I agree to a great extent. But I still believe that readable code is better than clever code for most cases, which makes writing more code justifiable in that case.
